 One of the most common critiques of the Framers is that the government that they created was, in many ways, undemocratic. There is little doubt of this, and it is so by design. The Electoral College, by which we choose our President, is one example. The appointment of judges is another. And the selection of Senators not by the people but by the state legislatures, is yet another. The Senatorial selection system eventually became fraught with problems, with consecutive state legislatures sending different Senators to Congress, forcing the Senate to work out who was the qualified candidate, or with the selection system being corrupted by bribery and corruption. In several states, the selection of Senators was left up to the people in referenda, where the legislature approved the people's choice and sent him or her to the Senate. Articles written by early 20th-century muckrakers also provided grist for the popular-election mill.
 
 The 17th Amendment did away with all the ambiguity with a simple premise - the Senators would be chosen by the people, just as Representatives are. Of course, since the candidates now had to cater to hundreds of thousands, or millions, of people instead of just a few hundred, other issues, such as campaign finances, were introduced. The 17th is not a panacea, but it brings government closer to the people. The Amendment was passed by Congress on May 13, 1912, and was ratified on April 8, 1913 (330 days).

 I'd like to clarify something about my point. I am not making an argument that the society should accept any and all "unconventional unions." I am suggesting that the burden of demonstrating why a particular form of marriage should not be allowed should fall on the state. There should be the presumption of liberty, with the states required to show that they have a legitimate reason or reasons for barring a particular form of marriage, beyond the fact that many people may disapprove of it or dislike the idea of it.
 
 It's obvious why marriage to animals should not be allowed, because marriage is a consensual relationship, and animals cannot consent to marriage. The state can easily justify a law prohibiting marriage between humans and animals, by showing a rational basis for such a prohibition and also a compelling state interest in such a prohibition. There is no group of human-animal couples pushing for the right to marry anyway. The idea of humans marrying animals is purely an imaginary scenario invented by the opponents of same-sex marriage. 
 
 Prohibitions on real forms of "unconventional unions" will likely be more difficult to justify and will require extended debate and consideration by states and by the courts. Two examples are polygamy, which is "conventional" in some societies, and marriages that many would regard as incestuous, such as first cousin marriages. First cousin marriages are currently allowed in 26 states, but not in all states. These are two examples of "unconventional unions" that I think states should have the burden of justifying their prohibitions against. There really are people in polygamous relationships who want the right to marry more than one spouse, and there really are cousins in relationships who want to marry each other. 
 
 The legalization of same-sex marriage will not and should not automatically make all other "unconventional unions" legal. Each form of marriage needs to be considered on its own terms, independently and specifically. That's why we need to discuss, and states and courts need to consider, the issue of same-sex marriage separately from a discussion of polygamy. While there are parallels between the two, the issues involved, and a state's reasons for barring them, are not exactly the same. 
 
 A number of people have objected to our repeated reference to the issue of inter-racial marriage, saying that we cannot equate race with sexual orientation. It's true that we cannot equate the two, and each form of marriage needs to be considered on its own terms. On the other hand, there are obvious parallels between the arguments against inter-racial marriage and the arguments against same-sex marriage, and it is often useful to draw parallels as well as to see distinctions between two forms of marriage. Ultimately, I think that we should embrace a presumption of liberty for people to marry the person of their choice, and the burden of showing why a form of marriage should be barred should fall on the state.

 This is an interesting post, and I did not have time to address it adequately back when you posted it. I think the issue here IS marriage, not "gay marriage." It's whether and under what circumstances a person should be restricted from marrying the person of his or her choice. So I think you are right that the issue is marriage itself, and under what circumstances the right to marry one's chosen spouse can and should be denied by the state.
 
 I have argued, and I continue to argue, that the burden should be on the state to justify disallowing people to marry; the burden should not be on individuals who seek to marry to justify their union. There should be a presumption of individual liberty, not a presumption of state power to deny individual liberty. Gay marriage is fundamentally no different from heterosexual marriage; both are marriage. The only difference between same-sex marriage and opposite-sex marriage is the sex (some use the term gender) of the spouses involved. Legalizing same-sex marriage does not fundamentally change the nature of marriage. In contrast, creating a separate category of civil unions DOES change the nature of marriage in that it creates a two-tier system of unions. (The same is true of the creation of covenant marriages in the few states that have created such marriages as a separate legal category. Only a tiny percentage of couples have chosen covenant marriages, and I suspect this legal category will disappear out of disinterest and lack of use.) 
 
 When a state seeks to deny certain couples the right to marry, and the state's denial is challenged in court, the state needs to make its case for prohibiting that type of marriage specifically. Each specific type of prohibition or restriction has to be considered independent of all the others, so that courts and the public can hear the rationale for that specific prohibition. 
 
 Gay people are not the first group of people to challenge marriage restrictions in court. We almost certainly will not be the last group. Marriage has not been an inflexible and unchanging institution; indeed, marriage has changed considerably through the course of history.  I have not argued, and neither has Leszek, that states cannot or should not be able to restrict the right to marry. My argument is that states must show a compelling state interest in restricting someone from marrying the person of his or her choice. States cannot and should not be able to bar marriages between two people simply because of prejudice against those people or because of some people's religious beliefs. 
 
 When I say that each type of restriction must be considered individually and separately from all the others, I am observing a legal and historical reality. States have various different reasons for restricting marriages. For example, states restrict marriages between adults and children for a different reason than they restrict marriages between people of the same sex. In considering 14th amendment challenges to state laws restricting marriage, courts are going to look at specific cases, not at all kinds of marriages together. When the Supreme Court considered the Virginia law banning marriage between people of different races, they did not then rule on restrictions on cousin marriages or on polygamous marriages. They considered the state's rationale for restricting inter-racial marriages, and they found that the rationale did not suffice to make that particular state restriction on marriage constitutional. Courts must and will consider challenges to different marriage restrictions separately from each other. 
 
 A court ruling in favor of same-sex marriage will not automatically eliminate all state restrictions on marriage, because each restriction must be considered on its merits. Massachusetts still bans marriages between adults and children, for example. The state supreme court ruling in favor of same-sex marriage did not eliminate all restrictions on marriage, just the one the court was then considering. If someone wants to challenge age restrictions on marriage, they will have to bring a lawsuit on that specific issue and make their arguments that the state does not have a compelling interest in banning adult-child marriages. I think it's clear that the state does have a compelling interest in banning such marriages, and I think anyone challenging such a ban is likely to lose, and should lose, their case.

 This provision was intentionally included in the constitution, certainly. There was much disagreement at the time of the framing of the constitution over whether the constitution gave the national government too much power and whether the rights of individuals would be trampled. A minority, the anti-federalists, opposed the ratification of the constitution because of this. They were particularly insistent that the constitution must have a bill of rights, to protect the rights of the people explicitly, before they could support it. The framers, the majority at the convention, gave in to this demand of the minority, the anti-federalists, and agreed to add a bill of rights in the form of the first ten amendments, in order to mollify the anti-federalist minority and get the constitution ratified by the states. These amendments became the Bill of Rights. 
 
 This is an example of how the requirement of what amounts to a super-majority for constitutional change actually helps to protect the interests of minorities. A simple majority cannot ram constitutional change down the throats of the minority. They have a very high hurdle to get over to change the federal constitution. We saw this recently with the proposed Federal Marriage Amendment, which was an attempt to define marriage in the U.S. constitution to exclude gay couples. A majority of Americans may have supported it (this is not entirely clear), but it stood no chance of becoming law because of the high hurdle of 2/3 majority of both houses of Congress plus 3/4 of the state legislatures required to amend the constitution. 
 
 Another example of this cut in the other direction, and that was the Equal Rights Amendment. A majority of Americans supported the ERA, according to polls. A majority of members of both parties in Congress supported the ERA, and it passed both houses by 2/3 majorities. But the ERA fell just short of getting enough state legislatures to ratify it. There was a constitutional amendment supported by the majority that failed to become part of the constitution, because of minority opposition. The provision for adding an amendment to the U.S. constitution actually amplifies the power of the minority by requiring what amounts to a super-majority in Congress and among the states.
